I wanted to look at every month, each nerd. Take in a second. What is a nerd? You don't have this word in Canada? Okay, folks, we need to educate the Canuck lady about Yankee idioms. What is a nerd? A geek. What's a geek? Gawky, awkward, homely. Yeah. Schnooky. Nebbish. Yeah, nebbish. That would be the Sanskrit. Yeah, it's sort of like, uh, huh? Dilbert. Yeah. Well, why was I drawn to look at each one of the nerds? Was that there was something different about these nerds? No, but not unrelated. Each one 100% gloried in his nerdiness. Okay? They were just like totally just manifesting themselves as the avatar of nerd without any this or that. So it's what my teacher calls a full manifestation of that self. And it was beautiful. It was attractive. So the lesson there is that they didn't fixate or resist their self-consciousness. And it turned into something beautiful. And it's quite true. It's quite true. So when these aspects of experience come up, you now have the categories and you know that you can work with them. Allow the self to arise, churned into existence moment by moment. And then in a sense, everything you do will be beautiful. So when self-consciousness comes up, when self-judgment comes up, this is premier opportunity. It's the core of the core. Okay? If talk, image and feel is the core of the self, then those talk, image and feel are the core of the core. I said I wanted to be crystal clear about the categories. Talk includes, in my formulation, tunes, internal tunes. If you find you're doing lyrics or whatever. But it excludes something like ringing in your ear or tinnitus. Sometimes people ask is that part of talk. And of course it certainly excludes external sound. So if you're attending to internal talk, you would ignore external sounds and you would also ignore things like ringing in your ears. But you would include things like tunes that you can't stop humming. Anybody ever get that phenomenon? My favorite is Sergeant Pepper's Lonely Hearts program. The original. That to me is part of the internal dialog. Basically, if you're not filling it with dialog, you just fill it with music. Okay? Because we're in the habit of filling it with something. By the way, one thing that you might find productive if you get internal tunes that you just can't stop and it's annoying to you, is if it's annoying, it's annoying. That means that there is a body sensation associated with your reaction to the presence of that tune. And you may not be able to do much with the tune, but you can observe the sense of annoyance or imposition as a tangible body sensation, which is quite interesting. But one thing that you may discover is, you may discover that you have another flavor of sensation associated with those internal tunes. And you know what that flavor of sensation is? The pleasure of being amused by it. My internal tunes didn't go away until I was able to simultaneously be aware, at exactly the same moment, of both the sensation of being annoyed that I couldn't get rid of the tune, and the subtle sensation of being entertained by the tune. When I was able to simultaneously detect and have equanimity with those two sensations is when the tunes went away. Just share that with you for what it's worth. With respect to image, image for me means visual mental processing. That means that splashes of color or geometric patterns that you may see, or the light that comes in through your eyelids, is not part of mental image. Mental image means a mental image. It doesn't mean that it's clear like a photograph, but it is a form that you're using to think. By that I mean to remember something, to plan something, to fantasize something, to know what just produced the sound when your eyes are closed, to remember where you are and what you look like. This is what I mean by mental image. When you talk about geometric mental image, are you talking about visual geometric or image geometric? Am I being clear? Yes, that would not be part of mental image. Sort of kaleidoscopic type, that I would also not include as mental image. No. Basically you're not thinking with that, even though it's internally generated. Those splashes of color and kaleidoscopes and geometric forms are to the image process what the ringing in your ears is to the internal conversation. You're not really using it as a medium to think in. So ringing in your ears is not a sound that comes from the outside, but it's not something you think with. And splashes of colors, the proverbial purple clouds, kaleidoscopic type things, they're internally generated. They're not coming from the outside, but you're not really thinking in those images. So I don't count those as image. If you're entertaining yourself with kaleidoscopic, I suggest you focus on the flavor of the image. Being entertained. But by and large, what I'm trying to get you to do is penetrate the thinking process. So in my own vocabulary, I call the sounds that you hear that are sort of like tinnitus or ringing in your ear, that, whatever, I call it pseudo sound, because it's not really from the outside, but it's not really internal talk or tune. And forms that you may see that are like splashes of color or kaleidoscopic, I call that pseudo light, because it's more like light than it is like a mental image. Now if you see a Buddha and it's sort of radiating light and whatever, that would be a mental image, of course. Basically, subtle as I use it, is a default category. By that I mean, anything that's not, if you don't have any image at all, that's one extreme. If you have a clear image that you can say it's this or that, that's another extreme. And then we need to have a term for the whole range of stuff that's in between. It's not an absence, but it's not a clear presence, so I call that subtle. Analogously with the internal conversation. Okay, good. Are there any other questions about that? I know this is sort of picky, but the devil is in the details. I once heard Upendita say that even the batting of your eyelash completely changes consciousness. Okay, so to really know exactly what we're focusing on and what we're not focusing on at any given moment is very important. The name of the game in this practice is selective attention. Attention can be broad or attention can be narrow. That's not the issue. The issue is when you've defined what you are selectively attending to, you have partitioned the realm of experience into two mutually exclusive subsets. That which you are focusing on, which may be broad or narrow, and everything else. And until you intentionally change your defined object of meditation, you mercilessly ignore, to the best of your ability, anything that is not in your defined object of meditation. Because what you are attempting to do is develop a momentum, a critical mass of unbroken attentiveness with regard to the object of focus. Because it's only when you get unbroken attentiveness that the essential waveform can present itself. So if your object of meditation is mental image, as soon as you define your object of meditation as mental image, you may discover that your body just explodes. And as soon as you define your object of meditation to be internal conversation, you may discover that the images just explode. And then people say, what should I do? Until you have intentionally changed your object of focus, even though the competing thing may explode a thousand times more intensely than your defined object of focus, you stay with your defined object of focus. And do what? Monitor the impact of the competing phenomenon on your object of focus. There are only the following possibilities. A competing phenomenon will either stimulate the object of focus, or it will cause the object of focus to become quiescent, or it will have no effect at all. But your job is to know that and not let yourself get pulled as much as possible into the competing thing. Until you've changed, and you can change frequently, but you intentionally change. So that you get that sense of developing this momentum of continuity of contact until the thing starts to soften and show you its essential spirit form. So I think that's what I want to say about that. Yes, was there a question in the back? I was thinking about, there's something called the nada sound? Nada, N-A-D-A. Of course in Spanish it's something else, but nada in Sanskrit means a sound. But specifically, it often refers to what's called nada yoga, which is meditation on subtle sounds that you hear inside your ear. Like ringing in the ear or tinnitus type sounds. Except if you focus on those sounds, the more you focus on them, the more interesting they become and then you start to notice harmonics. And basically what you attempt to do is detect the subtle overtones. And of course that makes you, you have to get very concentrated. When you listen to a whisper, you get very concentrated. And then behind those subtler ones, you detect subtler ones and subtler ones. And it's basically a way of developing, sort of taking you deep in consciousness and developing a lot of concentration power. It's basically a shamatha exercise from my perspective, not an insight practice. But it's used in Tibetan Buddhism also. It's called sound yoga. Q. It's a certain feeling? A. Well it's sounds that we hear on the inside. No one quite knows what causes tinnitus or ringing in the ears medically. But the organ of corti is extremely sensitive and apparently very small physical fluctuations there or perhaps in the vestibulo acoustic nerve will cause the perception of internally generated sounds. And there are whole paths for working just with that phenomenon. Q. You were speaking about a lot of attentiveness. Could you talk about that with regards to using a very wide focus? A. What becomes of the meaning of selective attention if your object of meditation is everything? In essence is what you're asking. In that case, this is something some of you have heard me talk about but I'll just briefly repeat it. There is a technical term in Pali, karnika samadhi. Samadhi has many meanings. It can mean concentration in general but it can also mean a concentration that is so great that you merge with the thing you concentrate on. A sense of penetrating or becoming. Karna means a short period of time, an instant. So karnika means for an instant. The idea being that if you have a broad focus, in fact even if you have a narrow focus, it makes no difference. Each phenomenon as it comes up is experienced with a kind of penetrating awareness. Your awareness sort of soaks into it and there's a sense of merging. Now if you're focusing at the tip of your nose, those mergings are with each teeny little impact as it arises. If you're focusing on all phenomena, those mergings are with each sense experience as it arises. So you may know the expression to make and break that's used in electronics. There's a make and a break. A connection is made and then a connection is broken, like on a keyboard. Well you sort of have this make break, make break, make break, where you merge with the object and then you break that merging and then there's a merging with another object that may be something vastly different. So if it's at the tip of your nose, it's the same thing over and over again. But there is with each little impact a sort of make break, make break, make break of a merging. All that happens when you do it large is that it's large. You hear a sound and for that moment there's nothing but that sound and there is a clear sense of samadhi with that, for just a second, with that sound. And then that samadhi is broken and there's a body sensation and there's this clear sense of samadhi with this body sensation. It's made and then it's broken and then there's the next thing that comes up and there's a merging with it. So that even though the objects are distributed through space and are very different in terms of their character, each one has a momentary, tangible sense of having been experienced with high concentration. Therefore, the sense of focus that you would get if you were able to hold your concentration at the tip of your nose for two hours and the sense of focus that you would get if your awareness were going all over the universe, but palpably merging with each sense experience as it comes up, those two experiences would be indistinguishable. Because the second one is an unbroken sequence of samadhi. So it adds up to the same thing as a very narrow focus. I don't know if that makes any sense, but that's how it's described. You just have to sort of get a feel for this one. The Mahasi tradition, the Mahasi Sayadaw tradition, which is sort of the mainstream vipassana from Burma, considers this, what I've just said, to be of the utmost importance. And their acharyas, their sayadas, are always trying to sort of describe what I'm now describing. As your mindfulness develops at that moment of merging, the whole thing is just a waveform. You actually experience the impermanence of it right then and there, even though it's only for a short period of time. That's one of the reasons that we do these retreats, because it takes day after day after day after day after day after day to finally build up the ability to do that. I remember by the end of a two-month retreat with the Burmese master Upandita, they had, and it was a real source of aversion, they had a grandfather clock or some sort of very noisy clock in the meditation hall, that was constantly going tick tick tick tick. You could constantly hear it. And of course, you're supposed to work with whatever comes up. By the end of that two months, I could detect the beginning, middle and end of the tick, and the beginning, middle and end of the tock, each time. It was like it just bubbled up from the universe and returned. But of course, it took a long, long time to develop that. So when you get that khanika samadhi, it's an insight samadhi. It's not only that palpable sense of penetrating, but it's sort of like you penetrate it with awareness and it melts. And then you go to the next thing and you penetrate it with awareness and it melts. You've got to get a feel for it. I think I'm way beyond my time here. And I had intended to talk less because my mouth ain't in good shape. But you see what happened. So I thank you for your patience. And I congratulate you for sitting in the same room with Bodhidharma, because the vibe I get is that you guys are sitting like this guy.

The terms from Indian languages, Sanskrit primarily, or other Indic dialects, usually
what the Chinese did is they would not transliterate. Occasionally they transliterated, but usually
they translated. They tried to find a way to express the Sanskrit word in idiomatic
Chinese, but they didn't really have a word for the deep states of dhyanic trance. That

chose a character that had the sound Chan, so it would match the sound. But it also contained
an interesting meaning. Probably those of you who aren't Chinese, you don't know how
to write Chinese, I guess by and large, but Chinese characters are not just arbitrary
collections of strokes. They're built on very specific and very interesting structural principles.
Basically there are two parts to the character. One of the parts gives you a general sense
of the area that the character corresponds, how can I put it, gives you a general sense
about the meaning of the character. And another part of the character is the phonetic, gives
you a general sense of its sound. So there are 200 or so characters, it's sort of like
a classification scheme of basic categories of objects or relationships. And those are
called the radicals because they correspond to roots in Western languages. And then those
radicals are put together with phonetics, and so when you see a Chinese character, you
have some general idea of the domain that that character refers to, and you have a general
idea of how it's pronounced, even if you've never seen the character before, you could
probably figure out what it is. For example, one of the radicals, this is the sun radical,
but originally it was written like that, which of course is a much more realistic representation
of the sun. Or you can have the tree radical. In modern Chinese, it doesn't look too much
like a tree. Maybe it looks a little like a tree. But in archaic Chinese, you could
see the branches and the root very clearly. That's the tree radical. There's a bamboo
radical. There's a human radical. Anything that has this thing on the side refers to
something in the human realm. There's an animal radical. There is a plant radical.
There's an herbaceous plant. We'll have the plant radical. There's also a religion radical,
a piece that when you see it on characters, usually indicates that that character has
something to do with religion or a ritual or spirituality or something like that. If
I drew the radical fully, the religion radical fully, this is what it would look like. A
pparently it's originally the picture of the night sky and stars sending rays of light
down so that people would do astrological divination or signs from the heavens. Some
people think. That's why it also means to indicate as well as having a general sense
of spirituality. For example, the Chinese character for a spirit, shan, you can see
it has the religion radical and this is the phonetic that gives you the pronunciation
shan, which the Japanese pronounce shin, as in Shinto, the way of the gods. Can you see
it from back there, Yanlu? Shanfu. Shanfu means literally God Father, but it's the Chinese
word for a Roman Catholic priest. So there was a Chinese character that was pronounced
chan and it actually referred to the ceremony whereby a king appoints his successor. What
do we call that? The ceremony of succession to the throne. But it was pronounced chan.
So they decided to use that character just for its sound value. I don't know if you can
see it in the back, but for chan to stand for the Sanskrit word. But they were very
clever, very clever because not only does it have the radical that tells you it has
something to do with spirituality and this phonetic here that gives you the sound chan,
but this phonetic has its own meaning. This phonetic means singleness. So looking at the
character, not only does it have the sound chan, but it has a visual implication of show
or indicate or manifest singleness. And so it has connotations that cannot be captured
easily in English. So what does it mean to manifest singleness? Some Zen masters explain
Zen by parsing the character in the way that I just described. They'll say, what is Zen?
Zen is to manifest singleness. It's also true in the religion of the West, in Catholicism,
in the Middle Ages. The entire spiritual endeavor was called simplificatio, simplification.
Meditation, what we now call meditation, was referred to as simplificatio or simplification.
In Greek haplosis. Sanctus simplicitus, have you ever heard that? Holy simplicity. It was
held out as an ideal. Now if you take the Latin word simplex, what does it literally
mean? Simplex. Well, it means single fold as opposed to multiplicity, which means a
many foldedness. So how do we come to sanctus simplicitus, this holy simplicity? How do
we manifest singleness as this character connotes? Well, the way I like to look at it is that
the content of our experience is immensely, immensely complex. However, there is a unifying
principle. However complex the content of an individual experience may be, all experience
comes to us through six sense gates. I don't know of any experience that is not some combination
or subset of hearing, seeing, smelling, tasting, body sensation, and thinking. So we can reduce
the infinity of complexity to the relative simplicity of different combinations and subsets
of sense experience by keeping track of the sense components. But of course, that gives
us an experience that is six fold, not one fold. Once we can get down to experiencing
the world in terms of the coming and going of our sense gates, then we can start to see
that all of these sense gates have something in common. There is an underlying movement
in nature that presents itself in the sense gates, in the changing intensities and shapes
and rhythms of our sense gates. We come to experience the basic forces of expansion and
contraction. You may have a sensation that seems very pressured, very solid, but as you
inquire, does it want to push out, does it want to pull in, does it do both at the same
time, you'll usually get an answer. And you'll be able to experience that sensation in terms
of these fundamental forces. So that the six sense gates at some point start to present
wave, vibration, undulation. And you're now aware of just two basic activities, although
they are interwoven in various ways. You're aware of a force of increase and a force of
decrease, a force of affirmation, a force of negation, a force that pushes out, a force
that pulls in. So now the complexity of the six senses is reduced to the simplicity, relative
simplicity of impermanence. But you're not yet into true simplification, one-foldness,
because there's two-fold. There's expansion and contraction, there's spread and collapse.
